newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan urges India to discuss Kashmir.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan urges India to discuss Kashmir.

text.p: Pakistan said on Thursday it wanted India to discuss all issues dividing the two old foes, including the key dispute over the Himalayan region of Jammu and Kashmir.
A Foreign Ministry spokesman told reporters that talks between Prime Ministers Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan and Inder Kumar Gujral of India in the Maldives next week had no set agenda.
"We hope all outstanding issues between the two countries will come under discussion," he said.
Sharif and Gujral are due to meet on Monday on the fringes of a seven-nation South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) summit in the Maldivian capital Male.

Apparently rejecting Gujral's statement in parliament on Wednesday that Kashmir was an integral part of India, the spokesman said: "We hope he can bring himself to discuss all outstanding issues, including what we believe is the core issue of Jammu and Kashmir."
He said Gujral himself had stated his Male talks with Sharif would be very useful and added: "We hope this meeting will set the tone for future negotiations between the two countries."

He disagreed with a suggestion that Pakistan's insistence on making Kashmir a core issue might hamper progress in ties between the two states, which have fought three wars since independence from Britain in 1947. Two of them were over Kashmir.

"All I will say here is that if you go to a doctor with certain symptoms and he keeps on giving you aspirin to cure your symptoms and ignores the disease, you are not going to get better," he said. "I think India-Pakistan relations fall in the same category."

India is fighting a separatist Moslem revolt in the two-thirds of Kashmir it rules. Pakistan rules the rest of the former princely state, where armies of the two countries face each other across a United Nations-monitored control line.
India regards the whole of Kashmir as its own.
Islamabad says that predominantly Moslem Kashmir must decide in a U.N.-mandated plebiscite whether to join Islamic Pakistan or Hindu-majority India.
Some of the militant groups fighting Indian rule want to reunite the two parts of Kashmir in an independent state.
The two neighbours resumed talks in March after a three-year break marked by bitter recrimination.
Gujral met Pakistani Foreign Minister Gohar Ayub Khan last month before becoming prime minister in a political shakeup.
